title: How to Build a Hydroponic Garden

steps.title: Build the flood table.
steps.content: Build the flood table. The flood table will hold the water for the garden. You can build a simple flood table out of wood. The width of the flood table will depend on how much you want to grow in the garden and how much water you want to use. [1] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source For a small garden, make a rectangular frame out of treated lumber that is 4 feet, 1-inch (1.2 metres, 2.54 cm) wide by 8 feet, 1-inch long (2.4 metres, 2.54 cm). Then, line it with a polyethylene plastic sheet. This will hold 20 gallons (75 L) of water. You can also use a wide, deep plastic tray as the flood table. Pick a container that can hold 10 to 20 gallons (38 to 75 L) of water. You may want to line the tray with plastic to ensure it does not leak.

steps.title: Make a floating platform out of styrofoam.
steps.content: Make a floating platform out of styrofoam. To prevent the roots and soil of the plants from rotting, make a floating platform so they can float in the water. For a small garden, use a 4 by 8 foot (1.2 by 2.4 metre) sheet of 1 ½ inch (3.8 cm) thick styrofoam. Check that the edges of the platform can move up and down so the plants can float. [2] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source

steps.title: Cut 2 to 3 inch (5 to 7 cm) wide holes in the platform.
steps.content: Cut 2 to 3 inch (5 to 7 cm) wide holes in the platform. Use a plant pot as a guide when cutting the holes with a saw. Cut enough holes to fit all the plants you want to grow. Make sure the plant pots fit snuggly in the holes and do not extend beyond 1/16 inch (0.4 cm) below the styrofoam platform.

steps.title: Add drip emitters to the flood table.
steps.content: Add drip emitters to the flood table. Drip emitters help to drip out water from the garden to ensure the water does not sit stagnant in the flood table. You can find them in the irrigation supply section at your local hardware store or nursery. They come in different drip rates, based on maximum gallons per hour (gph). [3] X Research source For a standard garden, you want the flood table to hold 5 gallons (19 L) of water per hour. So, get two drip emitters that have a rate of 2gph. Puncture two holes in the bottom of the flood table. Then, push the drip emitters into the holes. Seal any gaps around the drip emitters with epoxy or hot glue.

steps.title: Place the flood table on a stand with a bucket.
steps.content: Place the flood table on a stand with a bucket. The flood table will need to be elevated on a stand or stool. Place a bucket under the flood table, directly underneath the drip emitters. The bucket will catch the water as it drips out of the flood table. [4] X Research source If you are growing the hydroponic garden outside, place it in a sunny spot in your yard. Position the flood table so it gets a maximum amount of sun.

steps.title: Fill the flood table with water.
steps.content: Fill the flood table with water. Pour enough water to fill the flood table halfway. Depending on the size you have chosen for your flood table, this may require 5 to 20 gallons (19 to 75 L) of water. [5] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source You can always add more water to the flood table once you add the crops.

steps.title: Set up grow lights if you are growing indoors.
steps.content: Set up grow lights if you are growing indoors. Hydroponic gardens can be grown outdoors in warm climates, especially climates that tend to get year-round sunlight. If you are growing the garden indoors, you will need grow lights. Use metal halide lights or sodium bulbs. [6] X Research source Position the grow lights over the flood table so it gets a lot of light.

steps.title: Get plant food.
steps.content: Get plant food. You will then need to add nutrient-rich plant food or fertilizer to the water so the plants can thrive. Look for plant food rich in calcium, magnesium, and other nutrients at your local plant supply store or gardening center. You can buy plant food specifically formulated for a hydroponic garden. It will be rich in the nutrients needed for plants grown in water.

steps.title: Go for leafy greens and herbs.
steps.content: Go for leafy greens and herbs. Hydroponic gardens are best for plants with shallow roots, such as leafy greens like lettuce, spinach, and kale. You can also grow herbs like mint, basil, and dill. [7] X Research source Choose plants that have similar light and water needs. This way, when they grow close together in the garden, they all do well and thrive. As you expand your hydroponic garden, you may be able to grow vegetables with deep roots like beets, squash, and cucumbers. Start small by choosing just 1 or 2 plants to grow. All plants have different needs in terms of nutrients, and will require a specific fertilization schedule. It's easiest to start with 1-2 plants so you can figure out which nutrients you need and learn what issues to watch for (and how to correct them).

steps.title: Make the potting mixture.
steps.content: Make the potting mixture. Start with a base that will provide moisture and air for the plants. Use eight parts perlite and one part coco fiber. You can also use vermiculite or peat moss instead of coco fiber. [8] X Research source If you live in an arid climate, add more coco fiber to the perlite. For a humid climate, add less coco fiber.

steps.title: Put the mixture in planting pots.
steps.content: Put the mixture in planting pots. Use 4-inch pots that have holes on the bottom, or netted planting pots. The holes will allow the plants to get water and plant food in the hydroponic garden. Fill the pots ⅓ of the way with the mixture.

steps.title: Plant the crops.
steps.content: Plant the crops. Use sprouted seedlings in cubes of soil. Place the cube with the started seedling in the pot. Pour media around the sides and top of the plant. It should be snug in the pot. [9] X Research source Using seedlings that have already been planted and started will make it easier for you to get your garden off the ground. Put one cube of started seedlings per pot.

steps.title: Place the crops in the flood table.
steps.content: Place the crops in the flood table. Water the crops lightly and then place them in the flood table. If you are using a floating platform, place the pots in the cut holes. If you are not using a floating platform, simply place them in the water in the flood table. [10] X Research source Make sure the roots of the plants are submerged in the water only ⅙ of an inch. This will ensure the roots do not get too wet but still get enough water to thrive.

steps.title: Water the plants once a day.
steps.content: Water the plants once a day. Water the plants at the base every day. If they start to wilt, water them twice a day. You should also add more water to the flood table if it starts to look scarce. [11] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source If the plants do not thrive as much as you’d like, they may not be getting enough air and too much moisture. Check if the roots of the plants are rotting. If they are starting to rot or smell, move them higher up so their roots are less submerged in the water.

steps.title: Add more plant food as needed.
steps.content: Add more plant food as needed. The water in the flood table should drip slowly out through the drip emitters into the bucket underneath. This can take seven to 10 days. As this happens, add a fresh batch of plant food to the bucket and more water. Then, pour the contents of the bucket into the flood table. [12] X Research source This will ensure the plants get the nutrients they need as they grow in the hydroponic garden.

steps.title: Confirm the plants are getting enough light.
steps.content: Confirm the plants are getting enough light. If you are growing the hydroponic garden outdoors, make sure the plants get constant, direct sunlight 10-15 hours a day. If you are growing the garden indoors, have grow lights on the plants for 15-20 hours. Set up the lights on a timer so they shut off automatically at a set time each day. [13] X Research source You can buy grow lights that come with a timer. Or you can set a timer yourself and shut off the grow lights as needed.

steps.title: Harvest the garden as it grows.
steps.content: Harvest the garden as it grows. Use clean gardening shears to trim the garden. Prune the garden for size and for eating. Cut leaves for eating at the stem. Harvest your yield as it grows so it thrives. You can then add new plants to the flood table or replace existing plants based on your needs.
